qas.question: Who proved that air is necessary for combustion?

context: In the <a6_3><b11_0>late <a6_0><a6_1><a6_2>17th<a6_2/><a6_1/> century<a6_3/><a6_0/>,<b11_0/> <a0_0><a0_1><a0_3><a4_0><a4_1><a4_3>Robert <a0_2><a4_2>Boyle<a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> proved that air is necessary for <b9_0>combustion<b9_0/>. English <b13_0>chemist<b13_0/> <a1_0><a1_1><a1_3><a8_0><a8_1><a8_3><b12_0>John <a1_2><a8_2>Mayow<b12_0/><a8_3/><a8_2/><a8_1/><a8_0/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> (<b10_0>1641–<a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3>1679<b10_0/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>) refined this work by showing that fire requires only a part of air that he called <a5_1><a5_2><a5_3>spiritus nitroaereus<a5_2/><a5_1/> or just <a5_0>nitroaereus<a5_3/><a5_0/>. In one experiment he found that placing either a mouse or a lit candle in a closed container over water caused the water to rise and replace one-fourteenth of the air's volume before extinguishing the subjects. From this he surmised that <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3>nitroaereus<a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> is consumed in both <a7_0><a7_1><a7_2><a7_3>respiration<a7_3/><a7_2/><a7_1/><a7_0/> and combustion.
